author: tsuigeo
content: Hey guys im trying to wrap my head around how merkle patricia tries operate. From what i understand, given a list of edge nodes (the leafs) we can reconstruct the root hash. My question is: dont the leafs need to be ordered in a certain way to end up with the same root hash? How do we know when given the list of transactions whats the right order to hash these transactions in to recover the root hash?

author: jiekai9348
content: I also want to better understand the various hash calculation process.  I think working through a blockchain test would help.

author: jiekai9348
content: https://ethereum-tests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/blockchain-tutorial.html

author: tsuigeo
content: I thought through it a bit more and i think it must be that the list of transactions be listed in alphabetical hex order and grouped according to whether they have the same character at a particular position of their address? Am i on the right train of thought here?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Transactions in a block are ordered by the miner (usually by gas price)
The state root is produced by applying all transaction to the statedb, the values in the statedb are the leafs for the merkle-patricia tree (and they are ordered by path)

author: tsuigeo
content: Right so the client has to reorder the transactions in the block from the miners given list to by path? And by path thats by hex alphabetical order?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The client gets the transaction in an order defined in the block, it does not need to reorder the transactions

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: It executes the transactions and applies the modifications to the trie

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The trie contains the accounts and storage slots of all contracts

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: They leafs of the trie are ordered by path in hex alphabetical order

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: But the trie has nothing to do with the ordering of the transactions

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: *not much

author: tsuigeo
content: This is for the use case of adding new leafs into the existing state trie the client already has right?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yes

author: tsuigeo
content: I was just considering the claim that if a client is given a list of all the leaf nodes that is all they need for reconstructing the root hash (as a property of merkle patricia tries in general)

author: tsuigeo
content: But what you say makes sense
